competencies.title: Build a Life Plan
competencies.description: Explain the elements and importance of developing a life plan.

levels.title: Life Plan Key Concepts
levels.description: deposit Green Granite Mouse support
levels.content:
Life Plan Key Concepts

Introduction

In this section, you will learn about the foundational concepts and components of developing a life plan.

Instructions

Watch the clip below featuring Shellye Archambeau, author of Unapologetically Ambitious  and watch up to the 39 minute mark.

Once you have watched the clip, read pages 45-49 of Unapologetically Ambitious and focus on what the author teaches about life planning.

After reading through the recommended section of the book, watch the following TEDx clip featuring Shellye Archambeau about "Knowing Your Power."

Review

You should now have a basic grasps of the fundamental concepts of creating a life plan as per the instruction of author Shellye Archambeau.

Call to Action

Start thinking about where you want to be ten, twenty, or even thirty years from now. Think about your future from both a professional and personal perspective.

Move forward with additional learning activities focused on planning and goal setting to learn how to turn your ambitions into an action plan.

title: Aspire  Platform
description: Learn how to use the Aspire  competency-based upskilling platform.

competencies.title: Competency Components
competencies.description: Describe & define competency components.

levels.title: Define competency
levels.description: Soap quantifying Fish protocol tan Tasty convergence Table
levels.content:
Define Competency

Introduction

In this section, you will learn about competencies. By the end of the section, you should be able to define what competency is and its primary components.

Instructions

Read the following text about competencies:

Aspire Ability defines a competency as an area of capability. While the granularity of a competency is flexible (and the subject of much debate), our rule of thumb is that a competency generally manifests as a bullet-pointed item on a job description.

Competencies are the foundational elements of what allows a person to perform in a job or complete a task.

Competencies are made up of three components: Knowledge, Skill, and Ability. Information about Knowledge, Skill, and Ability, or (KSAs), can be found in the "Define Knowledge, Skill, & Ability" learning activity.

Review

You should now be able to define what a competency is and where it fits, particularly in relation to doing a job.

Call to Action

If you have not already done so, go through the "Define Knowledge, Skill, & Ability" learning activity to deepen your understanding of the foundational elements of a competency.

levels.title: Define knowledge, skill, & ability
levels.description: Pass Fantastic generating Malta Web budgetary
levels.content:
Define Knowledge, Skill, & Ability

Introduction

In this section, you will learn about the difference between knowledge, skill, and ability and the differences between them.

Instructions

Read the following text about competencies:

Knowledge, Skills, and Abilities are what make up a competency. A competency can be defined at either the Knowledge (K), Skill (S), or Ability (A) level, so it is important to understand the distinct differences between each.

 

Knowledge - The foundational proficiency level for a competency. It includes the capacity to define, recognize, and describe the foundational principles and concepts related to a competency.

Example: I can explain that gravity is the invisible force that keeps us grounded.

 

Skill - The capacity to apply and analyze the knowledge, tools, and processes related to a competency. Someone with skill is a proficient operator and implementer of a competency.

Example: I can perform simple calculations to determine the force with which gravity is pulling something to the earth.

 

Ability -

Capacity to synthesize the knowledge and skill related to a competency. Someone with ability is a leading implementer, coach and mentor, and thought leader related to the Competency. 

Example: I can teach others how to calculate how quickly a football will hit the ground after leaving my hand if I throw it upward at a 30° angle at approximately 26 miles per hour.

 

A competency can be required at any of these three levels, depending on the given context.

Review

You should now be able to explain the difference between knowledge, skill, and ability, and the implications of each in a competency-based context.

Call to Action

Make a list of the competencies you make use of on a daily basis. Once you have created this list, go back through it and think of the context for each. Based on the context of each, indicate whether you feel you need the knowledge, skill, or ability level of each competency.

competencies.title: Digital Credentials
competencies.description: Explain digital credentials.

levels.title: Explain digital credentials
levels.description: Tools Myanmar incubate contextually-based sexy Portugal copy withdrawal
levels.content:
Explain Digital Credentials

Introduction

In this section, you will learn about digital credentials. By the end of the section, you should be able to talk about what a digital credential is, and give a high-level overview of how they work.

Instructions

Read the following text about digital credentials:

A digital credential is a standards-based, digital representation of an organization’s competency assertion about an individual. Organizations can issue digital credentials at whatever level of granularity they see fit. However, Aspire Ability strongly believes that digital credentials should have stand-alone value for individuals and employers when determining an individual’s fit for a job. As such, digital credentials should generally be issued at the Competency and Competency Cluster levels.

Digital Credentials can be “stacked” to represent relevant competency groupings. Credential issuers determine the relevance of competency groupings. 

Verifiable claims are the building blocks of a lot of digital credentials today. Any credential following the Open Badges standard will utilize verifiable claims. Credentials with verifiable claims allow you to show proof of your competencies.

Verifiable Claims - Verifiable claims are digital issuances with metadata that break down who issued the credential and what was done to achieve the credential.

Review

You should now be able to explain what a digital credential is and how it is used. If you would like more information regarding digital credentials and the open badge standard, you can get it from one of the following locations.

  • Understanding Digital Credentials
  • Open Badges

Call to Action

Explore sources like Badgr and Credly to see the different ways in which digital credentials are being issued and utilized.

levels.title: Explain the Learning & Employment Record
levels.description: Borders Fantastic value-added alliance generate value-added
levels.content:
Explain the Learning & Employment Record

Introduction

In this section, you will learn about the new digital credential wallet known as the Learning & Employment Record (LER). You should walk away from this section with the capacity to explain to someone what the LER is, how it is used, and how it works.

Instructions

Go to LER Hub and skim over the LER Overview information. Once you have done so, return to this page and watch the following video. Then go over the information below.

What is the LER?

The LER is the up-and-coming digital wallet for digital credentials. Such credentials can be but are not limited to open badges, transcripts, certifications, etc.

How to use it

When using the Aspire Ability Aspire platform, each time you demonstrate competence you will receive a digital credential. Each digital credential will automatically be uploaded to your LER. Eventually, you will be able to add any and all digital credentials you own to your LER.

When you need to show someone proof of the competencies you possess, you can pick and choose which credentials you share with a third party and what you keep private. 

How it works

The LER is your personal credential wallet. You have complete control of how you share your credentials. The LER will follow you through life, allowing you to build your credential portfolio at every turn.

Review

The Learning & Employment Record is where all of your digital credentials will live. It gives you the ability to share the credentials you want with who you want when you want.

Call to Action

Do a mental inventory of all your digital credentials, including transcripts, degrees, certifications, etc. Now think of how many different places you would have to go to in order to access all of your credentials. Wouldn't it be so much simpler if it all lived in one place? Enter the LER...

competencies.title: Aspire Platform
competencies.description: Describe the Aspire platform.

levels.title: Describe nearskilling
levels.description: solid compelling Soft open-source override Concrete
levels.content:
Describe Nearskilling

Introduction

In this section, you will learn what nearskilling is and why it is important. Nearskilling is the focal point of what Aspire Ability does, using the Aspire platform.

Instructions

Read the following text about competencies:

The Aspire Ability Aspire tool is built on the idea of nearskilling. The nearskilling process is what enables learners to move forward with their current or desired job, as well as in their career as a whole. Understanding what nearskilling is will be an essential piece of knowledge as you move forward with Nearskill. Nearskilling is defined below:

 

Nearskilling - The process of acquiring the competency or competencies that provide the most immediate and substantial step forward in a desired job or career path.

Review

Nearskilling is the process that takes you from start to finish in your job and career goals. This is done by helping you acquire the competencies that are the most logical next step for you, based on your goals.

Call to Action

Thinking about the competencies you think you already possess and where you want to end up in your career, list out the competencies you feel you still need to obtain or improve on. Once you have your list, try to identify which competencies you should work on obtaining next based on your new understanding of nearskilling.

levels.title: Explain what Aspire does
levels.description: Saint Run haptic redefine Implementation facilitate Utah
levels.content:
Explain What Aspire Does

Introduction

Aspire is a competency-based, personal development and near skilling platform. The Aspire tool enables users to grow nearer to their desired career outcomes by providing job-specific learning pathways and evidence of job-aligned competencies.

Instructions

The video below provides a brief overview of the Aspire platform. Watch the video, then make your way to the review section to wrap up what you learn.

Review

The video above showed how the Aspire Ability Aspire platform aids you in nearskilling toward your desired job or career outcome. This is done by providing personalized, job-specific learning pathways. Once you demonstrate the required competencies for a pathway, you are awarded digital, verifiable credentials, which are then added to your personal Learning & Employment Record. Each credential puts you one step closer to proving you are a qualified candidate for your desired job.

Call to Action

Now that you have an understanding of what Aspire is and how it works, get started with the "Access" competency cluster to get started with your Aspire account.

competencies.title: Getting to the Platform
competencies.description: Locate the Aspire platform.

levels.content:
Navigating to NearSkill

Introduction

In this section, you will learn how to navigate to the Aspire platform.

Instructions

Type the following URL into your internet browser: nearskill.Aspire ability.com

 

You should now be able to log in, or create an account if you do not already have one.

Review

You should now be able to make your way to the Aspire platform.

Call to Action

Once you are ready, head over to the section about logging in and out to get started with NearSkill.

competencies.title: Login and Logout
competencies.description: Describe how to access the platform online.

levels.title: Log in and out of NearSkill
levels.description: Architect azure Angola Health Coordinator Shoes Solomon program Rubber
levels.content:
Log In & Out of NearSkill

Introduction

In this section, you will learn how to navigate to log in and log out of the Aspire platform.

Instructions

At this point, you should be at the login page for NearSkill.

To log in to the platform, enter your Aspire associated email and password. If you don't already have an account, click "Create an Account." If you forgot your password, click "Forgot Password?"

 

Once you have entered your credentials, go ahead and hit the "Sign In" button. You should now have access to NearSkill.

To log out of the platform, simply click the logo in the top right corner for mobile, or navigate to the menu bar on the left side of the screen for desktop, and select the "Log Out" button. This should completely sign you out of your account and return you to the login screen.

Review

You should be able to log into your Aspire account, giving you access to all of your nearskilling pathways. Additionally, you should know how to log out of your account.

Call to Action

It's time to read up on how to navigate Nearskill. Head over to the navigation competencies to learn more.

competencies.title: Navigating Aspire Pathways
competencies.description: Compare and Select Relevant Aspire Pathways.

levels.title: Browsing Recommended Aspire Pathways
levels.description: lavender Outlying invoice transmitter e-enable Shoes Global payment
levels.content:
Browsing Aspire Pathways

Introduction

In this section, you will learn how to navigate your suggested Aspire learning pathways and select the best pathway for you.

Instructions

Aspire has a variety of nearskilling pathways to aid you in achieving your career goals and obtaining the competencies you need. Based on your preferences and goals, Aspire will suggest pathways it thinks will be most beneficial to your nearskilling plan.

Step 1

Browse the suggested pathway library.

 

Step 2

Open up the details of pathways that interest you. Click through the specific competencies in the pathway and see what exactly it is you need to be able to do.

 

Step 3

When you find the pathway you want to engage in, click the "Enroll In Job Pathway" button.

 

Review

You should be able to browse learning pathways and enroll yourself in those pathways that best fit your career goals.

Call to Action

Make your way into Aspire and enroll in your first nearskilling pathway.

levels.title: Browsing Additional Aspire Pathways
levels.description: interfaces SQL Avon Gorgeous of
levels.content:
Browsing Aspire Pathways

Introduction

In this section, you will learn how to navigate your additional Aspire learning pathways and select the best pathway for you.

Instructions

Aspire gives you the option to enroll in as many nearskilling pathways as you want! If you want to engage in an additional pathway, follow the steps below.

Step 1

Browse the complete pathway library. You can filter pathways by job, competency, or company.

 

Step 2

Open up the details of pathways that interest you. Click through the specific competencies in the pathway and see what exactly it is you need to be able to do.

 

Step 3

When you find the pathway you want to engage in, click the "Enroll In Job Pathway" button.

 

Review

You should be able to browse learning pathways and enroll yourself in those pathways that best fit your career goals.

Call to Action

Browse the complete pathway library and search for additional Aspire pathways you would like to engage in.

competencies.title: Navigating Competencies
competencies.description: Compare and contrast competencies and improve your standing.

levels.title: Analyze Current vs Required Competencies
levels.description: yellow Loan deposit Accountability card models deposit Fantastic Togo
levels.content:
Analyze Current & Required Competencies

Introduction

In this section, you will learn how to analyze the way your current competency profile stacks up against the competencies required for your desired job or career goal.

Instructions

Aspire shows you where you stand in relation to your competency goals. When viewing a pathway, you can see all of the required competencies for your desired outcome.

On top of each competency layer, you can quickly view whether or not have demonstrated that competency. Those competencies with a checkmark have been demonstrated. Those competencies with an empty circle have not yet been demonstrated.

 

Review

You should be able to interpret where your current competency profile stands relative to where you want to be.

Call to Action

Take a look at where you are in your Aspire pathway in relation to the competencies you have demonstrated and the ones you have yet to acquire.

levels.title: Obtain the Competencies You're Missing
levels.description: SSL disintermediate Tools engage Optional 1080p Guernsey Gold
levels.content:
Obtain The Competencies Your Missing

Introduction

In this section, you will gain the skills you need to use the Aspire platform to obtain the competencies you need for your desired job or career goal.

Instructions

In NearSkill, when you are looking at your progression status for a learning pathway, you can a list of competencies, all of which are clearly marked as to whether or not you have demonstrated that competency.

The platform allows you to interact with each competency in order to effectively gain the competencies you still need, as well as to review past learning experiences.

To access the learning activities within a specific competency, simply follow the steps below.

Step 1

Select the competency you would like to work on.

 

Step 2

You will be presented with a playlist of learning activities, each one indicating the area of focus and KSA type for that activity. Select the learning activity you would like to engage with.

 

Step 3

At this point, you will be presented with a learning activity. Follow the instructions and utilize the resources within the activity to progress toward further competence in this area.

 

Review

This section walked you through the processes of Nearskilling specific competencies by engaging with KSA-specific learning activities.

Call to Action

Go into one of the competencies in your Aspire pathway and begin working on your first learning activity if you have not already done so.

competencies.title: Demonstrate Competence
competencies.description: Use Aspire assessments to demonstrate competence at varying proficiency levels.

levels.title: Demonstrate Competence at K, S, or A
levels.description: Dollar SSL Salad Money navigate eyeballs driver Avon AGP
levels.content:
Demonstrate Competence at K, S, or A

Introduction

In this section, you will review the distinctions between knowledge, skill, and ability and how they relate to competence. By the end of this section, you should be able to identify and describe generally the attributes of the competencies in your learning pathway at the knowledge, skill, and ability levels.

Instructions

Aspire competencies are broken into three different proficiency levels; Knowledge, Skill, and Ability. The attributes and definition for each can be found below.

Knowledge - The foundational proficiency level for a competency. It includes the capacity to define, recognize, and describe the foundational principles and concepts related to a competency.

Example: I can explain that gravity is the invisible force that keeps us grounded.

Skill - The capacity to apply and analyze the knowledge, tools, and processes related to a competency. Someone with skill is a proficient operator and implementer of a competency.

Example: I can perform simple calculations to determine the force with which gravity is pulling something to the earth.

Ability - Capacity to synthesize the knowledge and skill related to a competency. Someone with ability is a leading implementer, coach and mentor, and thought leader related to the Competency. 

Example: I can teach others how to calculate how quickly a football will hit the ground after leaving my hand if I throw it upward at a 30° angle at approximately 26 miles per hour.

 

Aspire utilizes authentic assessment techniques and best practices to evaluate your level of proficiency with each competency in your pathway. These assessments can take place in a variety of formats, ranging from rubric-based artifact uploads to rigorous multiple-choice evaluations.

 

Review

You should now be able to identify competencies at the knowledge, skill, and ability levels.

Call to Action

Select a competency in your current or desired NearSkilling pathway. Try to articulate the differences between the knowledge, skill, and ability levels for that competency.

levels.title: Remediate your KSAs
levels.description: Buckinghamshire Fantastic withdrawal Virginia Shoes transmit
levels.content:
Remediate Your KSAs

Introduction

This section breaks down the processes that take place when the minimum threshold for demonstrating competence at the K, S, or A level is not met.

Instructions

The Aspire platform is designed and built around the idea of proving competence. That being said, it is irrelevant how many times an assessment needs to be taken in order to prove said competence.

In situations where competence is not proven, the learned simply reviews the assessment feedback, and returns to the learning activities specific to the necessary areas of focus for that competency.

Example: Emma was trying to demonstrate her competence in data analytics, but didn't quite meet the needed criteria. In reviewing her assessment feedback, she gathered that she needed more help with calculating standard deviations of a data set. She went back into her learning pathway and reviewed the resources in the Skill learning activity for standard deviation.

Step 1

Review assessment feedback.

 

Step 2

Engage with the appropriate learning activity.

 

Step 3

Re-assess and re-demonstrate.

Review

You should now be able to engage in the remedial process for competency nearskilling.

Call to Action

Identify areas of competence in your learning pathway where you could use some extra work. Go back through the learning materials and activities for the appropriate section, and see if you have a better grasp on the given competency afterward.

competencies.title: Utilizing Credentials
competencies.description: Evaluate & share the right credentials at the right time and in the right place.

levels.title: Differentiating types of digital credentials
levels.description: customized Cotton Plastic Shoals Views
levels.content:
Differentiating Types of Digital Credentials

Introduction

This section will teach you how to parse varying types of digital credentials, particularly those most likely to show up in your Learning and Employment Record.

Instructions

You are likely to encounter a hand full of different types of digital credentials throughout your career. Such credentials can be things like open badges, transcripts, and other artifacts. Below are some of the more common credentials that you are likely to encounter in your LER.

Verifiable Claims

Verifiable claims are a digital assertion of an event, status, or truth. Simply put, when a verifiable claim is issued, it creates a digital trail to the issuer and/or verifier. This allows individuals observing the contents of the credential to see why it was issued and if it came from a credible source.

Example: Aspire Ability issued a verifiable claim as a credential that says Emma attended the mandatory sexual harassment seminar on June 30th, 2021 at her company. This credential shows the issuer as Aspire Ability, the assertion as attendance of the seminar, and the date of issuance. 

Open Digital Badges

Open badges are a type of digital credential, often containing verifiable claims, that make an assertion about an individual. In the context of the Aspire platform, badges are assertions of your competencies containing metadata about what you did to prove that competence.

Example: Aspire Ability issued a badge to Emma for competence in HTML 5 at a skill level. The badge states the competency, as well as the knowledge, skill, or ability associated with that competency. It also details what Emma had to do to prove her competence in this area.

Review

You should now be able to differentiate between verifiable claims and digital badges, the two most common credentials you will receive on the Aspire platform.

Call to Action

If you already have a credential in your LER, take a look inside it and try to determine what kind of credential it is, based on what you have learned here.

levels.title: Selecting & sharing credentials
levels.description: Branding Tools Grocery Corporate Gorgeous Electronics embrace
levels.content:
Selecting & Sharing Credentials

Introduction

In this section, you will learn how to share credentials with others, as well as how to monitor which credentials are shared and which remain private.

Instructions

The credentials in your Learning & Employment Record belong to you. As such, you have the right to share as many, or as few, of your credentials with third parties as you wish. The steps below break down the process of sharing a credential.

Step 1

Navigate to your Learning & Employment Record.

Step 2

Expand the credential that you would like to share.

Step 3

At the bottom of the page, select the sharing option you wish to use.

Review

You should now be able to share your credentials with others.

Call to Action

Go into one of your credentials, if you have one, and go through the process of sharing it with someone. *Note: You don't have to complete the sharing process if you don't want to send out your credential.
